MainHeading.P: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 10.30 a.m.

MainHeading.Title: Request to move Adjournment of Dáil under Standing Order 31.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Before coming to the Order of Business, I propose to deal with a number of topics under Standing Order 31 dealing with five different issues. I propose to deal with them separately and I will call on the Deputies in the order in which they submitted their notices to my office.
In regard to the first topic, I have received notice from Deputy Gogarty and I call on him to state the matter.
As Deputy Gogarty is not in the House we will move on to the second topic. I have received notice from Deputy Michael D. Higgins and I call on him to state the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Speaker.P: I seek leave to move the adjournment of the Dáil under Standing Order 31 to raise the following matter: the urgent need for the Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform to apologise on behalf of the State to Carolyn Swift for the disgraceful action of the police against the Pike Theatre on the occasion of its production of the “Rose Tattoo” in May 1957. Will the Minister acknowledge the impact this action by the police and the State had on the members of this small and courageous theatre? Will he now, as a gesture of goodwill, make such reparation as is appropriate to the surviving member of the company, the lives of whose members were irrevocably damaged by the actions taken in the name of the State.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Having considered the matter fully, I do not consider it to be in order in accordance with Standing Order 31.
In regard to the third topic, I received notice from Deputy Crowe. In regard to the fourth topic I have received notice from Deputies Timmins and Cuffe and I call on them to state the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Timmins Mr. Timmins
Speaker.P: I seek the adjournment of the Dáil under Standing Order 31 on a matter of national importance: the discovery by the EPA of levels of uranium 238 in the public water supply in Baltinglass, County Wicklow; the fact that there are no parametric values for uranium 238 in either national or EU drinking water regulations and there are no such values in the new regulations which will come into place in 2004; the consequences of this and what measures the Minister for the Environment and Local Government and the Minister for Health and Children propose to take to address the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cuffe Mr. Cuffe
Speaker.P: I seek the adjournment of the Dáil under Standing Order 31 on the same issue to discuss a matter of national importance: the high levels of uranium found in a County Wicklow well. Will the Minister for the Environment and Local Government instruct the Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland to work with local authorities in assisting households to monitor and prevent radioactive contamination of their drinking water supply?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Having considered the matter fully, I do not consider it to be in order in accordance with Standing Order 31.
In regard to the fifth topic, I have received notice from Deputy McManus and I call on her to state the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: I seek the adjournment of the Dáil under Standing Order 31 to discuss the following specific and important matter of public interest requiring urgent attention: the decision of the Government to renege on its commitment to extend medical card eligibility limits to bring in another 200,000 people and the need for the Government to indicate how it intends to address the primary health care needs of those on low incomes who do not qualify for medical cards.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Having considered the matter fully, I do not consider it to be in order in accordance with Standing Order 31.

MainHeading.Title: Order of Business.
MainHeading.P: Minister for Defence (Mr. M. Smith): The Order of Business today shall be No. 28, Sea Pollution (Hazardous and Noxious Substances) (Civil Liability and Compensation) Bill, 2000 – Second Stage (resumed); No. 29, Criminal Justice (Illicit Traffic by Sea) Bill, 2000 – Second Stage (resumed); No. 4, Interpretation Bill, 2000 – Order for Second Stage and Second Stage.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: There are no proposals to be put to the House. I call Deputy Kenny on the Order of Business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kenny Mr. Kenny
Speaker.P: In respect of defence legislation will the Minister confirm that the tender for three medium air lift helicopters for the Air Corps has been cancelled? Will he confirm that on Tuesday at the opening of the Air Corps conference he agreed that the personnel involved had put in great effort in regard to procurement and that his announcement was greeted with astonishment in Baldonnel?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: That is not appropriate to the Order of Business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kenny Mr. Kenny
Speaker.P: Under the legislation with which the Minister is reforming the defence forces, will—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Only the legislation and what is in it is appropriate. Is the legislation promised?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kenny Mr. Kenny
Speaker.P: The Minister might comment on that. It seems he will remain silent and that the Air Corps can forget about its helicopters.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: The Deputy must find another way to raise the issue.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: Will the Minister inform us when the Bill dealing with health complaints will be brought before the House and whether the 200,000 people who have been cheated of medical cards will be able to make complaints under the Bill for betrayal by the Government? This morning a Fianna Fáil backbencher told them to go and see their local community welfare officer.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Sorry Deputy, a question on the Bill itself only.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: Is that the Government answer, that they should go to see the community welfare officer?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Minister, when will the Bill be introduced?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: He promised 200,000 people would qualify for medical cards and will renege on that promise at the stroke of a pen. Can we underline procedure for the medical complaints legislation? Will these 200,000 people be able to make complaints under this legislation for betrayal and—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Deputy Rabbitte, allow the Minister to answer the question which was in order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: It will be introduced next year, 2003. Every promise we made in 1997 was honoured. We will honour this one also.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: It is not necessary, Minister, to go beyond the question that was asked.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: He promised 200,000 medical cards. Will he renege on that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Stagg Mr. Stagg
Speaker.P: He targeted the poorest. He should be ashamed.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Please allow Deputy Ó Caoláin to ask a question appropriate to the Order of Business.

Speaker.hpid: Caoimhghín Ó Caoláin Caoimhghín Ó Caoláin
Speaker.P: When will the Nurses Bill be published? I note it is listed for 2003, but will it be like the Fianna Fáil election promise in the programme for Government that 200,000 additional people would avail of the medical card scheme?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: This will be next year, 2003.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Timmins Mr. Timmins
Speaker.P: When can we expect to see the EPA (Amendment) Bill? While the Minister is on his feet perhaps he can indicate the steps the Minister for the Environment and Local Government and the Minister for Health and Children are taking to deal with the discovery of uranium in the water in Wicklow.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: The EPA (Amendment) Bill will be introduced this session. The RPI, the EPA and the Minister for the Environment and Local Government are working closely with the local authority, of which the Deputy is a member, with regard to the water problem in Wicklow. He is probably more up to date on what is happening.

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: I am sure the Minister will agree that, when the Government is negotiating with any organisation or body, it is important commitments are kept; otherwise any possibility of negotiation in the future is practically impossible.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Does the Deputy have a question appropriate to the Order of Business?

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: When the issue of medical cards for the over 70 year olds was raised by doctors in negotiations with the Government, a commitment was made by the Government to widen the income limits for medical cards.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: The Deputy is out of order.

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: I am asking a question.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: The Deputy will have to find another way to raise the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: I am asking about a Bill.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: The Deputy is not asking about a Bill; she is making a statement that is not related to a Bill.

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: I am asking about legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: The Deputy is asking about legislation.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: To what Bill is the Deputy referring?

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: The Medical Practitioners Bill, but I would like to make the point—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: It is not necessary to make a point at this stage.

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: —that any commitments made by the Government must be honoured. The Government misled the people and it also misled the medical profession about the position of people who cannot access their family doctors because they cannot afford to.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: The Bill will be introduced next year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cuffe Mr. Cuffe
Speaker.P: It is not often that Baltinglass makes national headlines, but the levels of radioactive contamination found in water raises a disturbing issue.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Does the Deputy have a question on promised legislation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cuffe Mr. Cuffe
Speaker.P: Will the water services Bill to consolidate and update water services legislation, which is expected in mid-2003, address the issue of contamination by radioactive substances?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: The Bill is due in mid-2003.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: The Government promised a local government rates Bill to consolidate rating law. Will the Minister include in that legislation the new layer of charges and taxes that have been imposed by local governments to compensate for the shortfall in Government funding for local authorities?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: We cannot discuss the content of the Bill at this stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: Will the Minister consolidate this new layer of taxes, which are essentially poll taxes?

Speaker.hpid: Ms O'Sullivan Ms O'Sullivan
Speaker.P: Thousands of families who expected to be included under the medical card scheme have had their hopes dashed this morning. They will not be able to afford to send their children for medical care.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Does the Deputy have a question appropriate to the Order of Business?

Speaker.hpid: Ms O'Sullivan Ms O'Sullivan
Speaker.P: In relation to the health medical indemnity Bill, how will the Government indemnify itself against the wrath of the Irish people?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: I call Deputy Power.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Stagg Mr. Stagg
Speaker.P: Members of the Government should be ashamed of themselves. The income limit to qualify for a medical card is €137 per week. The Government targets the poorest people.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Deputy Stagg, will you allow the Member for Kildare-South have his say?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Power Mr. S. Power
Speaker.P: The Deputy is usually very nice to me. Yesterday we learnt that a number of Members from both Houses are to visit the Columbia three. Would it not be more appropriate to discuss the matter in this House before any Members make such a visit?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: That is not in order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: With respect, it is an appropriate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Stagg Mr. Stagg
Speaker.P: It is a proposal from the Government side and we accept that.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: It is a matter for the Whips to discuss.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Costello Mr. Costello
Speaker.P: I agree with the suggestion that the matter be brought before the House to have a thorough discussion. Considering the Minister for Finance, Deputy McCreevy, has squandered the boom times, that promises have been broken wholesale and he is reneging on the medical card promise—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Does the Deputy have a question related to the Order of Business?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Costello Mr. Costello
Speaker.P: Will the Minister bring forward the dormant funds Bill so that funding can be made available immediately? We read today that bogus accounts are—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Please, give the Minister a chance to answer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: That will be next year, 2003.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: I call Deputy Crowe.

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: The Deputy asked a question. What about the legislation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: Do we not have rights on this side of the House? We have put a question and the Chair should allow the Minister to answer.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: When the Minister is called by the Chair, he is entitled to rise and to answer the House without interruption.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: He did not have the answer at the time. He has only just been briefed.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: I called the Minister to answer and he answered. If Deputies are interrupting and do not hear the answer, the Chair takes no responsibility for that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: He did not answer. Deputy Costello asked about the dormant funds Bill. Can we hear the Minister? Do we have any rights on this side of the House?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: If the Deputy resumes his seat the Chair will explain. The Deputy talked about medical cards. How is that related to the dormant funds Bill?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: That is not your affair, Sir; it is none of your business.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: If Deputies make—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: Deputy Costello asked about the dormant funds Bill and he made a comment to the effect that the funds could be used to fund the medical card—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Deputy Rabbitte, resume your seat, please. As the Deputy knows, it is the business of the Chair to ensure the Order of Business—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Stagg Mr. Stagg
Speaker.P: It is not the business of the Chair to make comments. The Chair is supposed to be impartial.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Deputy Stagg, when the Chair is on its feet, Members should resume their seats. The decision under Standing Order 26 is specific. Members are entitled to ask questions on promised legislation. It is not appropriate to make a long preamble or any preamble. In this instance Deputy Costello made a preamble about medical cards. If Deputy Costello has a question about a particular Bill the Minister will answer the question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Costello Mr. Costello
Speaker.P: I would like to clarify my question. It is proposed to introduce the dormant funds Bill. I am asking the Minister to bring it forward so that the broken promises of this Government in relation to the medical cards—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: It is not necessary to have a preamble on it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Costello Mr. Costello
Speaker.P: This would make money available in the budget.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: The aim is to have the heads of the Bill drafted by the end of this year. However the Minister favours including these proposals as part of the Courts (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Stagg Mr. Stagg
Speaker.P: On a point of order, it is not appropriate for the Chair to determine the form of question under the particular Standing Order. The attempt to sanitise the House to such a degree that it is like a closed clinic is what has the Gallery empty and the columns of the newspapers empty also. The Chair is in breach of the rules by seeking to determine the form and format of questions under the ruling here. The Chair is not so entitled.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: I am not dealing with the form.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Stagg Mr. Stagg
Speaker.P: The Chair is.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: It is not appropriate to have a long preamble to every question on the Order of Business.

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: This is a Parliament.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: The Chair has ruled on the matter and that is it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: Would the Chair like us to write to him and stay out of the House altogether? He could talk for us to the Government and we will stay away and write to him. Would the Chair prefer that?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Is the Deputy reflecting on the impartiality of the Chair?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Stagg Mr. Stagg
Speaker.P: It is not the Ceann Comhairle's job to ask questions.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: It is my job to ensure that the integrity of the Chair is protected in this House. Is Deputy Rabbitte reflecting on the integrity of the Chair?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: Sir, I merely posed a question. It is a matter for him—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: I am asking the Deputy if he is reflecting on the integrity of the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: I merely posed the question—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Stagg Mr. Stagg
Speaker.P: The Ceann Comhairle is supposed to be impartial.

P.i: (Interruptions.)

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Is the Deputy reflecting on the integrity of the Chair in his comments?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: No, I am not reflecting on the integrity of the Chair just on the format.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: In the forthcoming Social Welfare Bill, is it proposed, in line with a commitment given by a Fianna Fáil Deputy this morning, to amend a provision of that Bill to enable community welfare officers to issue medical cards to the poor and disadvantaged who have been denied them and to ensure—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Deputy Penrose knows he is out of order. Deputy Kathleen Lynch. Sorry, Deputy Seán Crowe.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Ring Mr. Ring
Speaker.P: I was the second person with my hand in the air and the Ceann Comhairle is passing me by.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: I want to know. I want answers from the Government—

P.i: (Interruptions.)

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Does Deputy Penrose have a question on legislation? What legislation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: Is it proposed in the Social Welfare Bill to include a provision to enable community welfare officers to—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: When will the Social Welfare Bill come before the House—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: —honour the promise the Government made—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: It is obvious to the Chair that Deputy Penrose is being disorderly and that he knows he is out or order—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: I have not been disorderly.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: It is appropriate to ask about legislation but not about the content of legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: I know what it is to have a medical card. Perhaps the Ceann Comhairle does not. My family was very glad of it—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Deputy Penrose—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: Maybe those people who look after the horse owners and breeders—

P.i: (Interruptions.)

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Deputy Penrose—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: Why did the Government not increase capital gains tax and ensure the ordinary working class people got a medical card? I will stand up for these people. I am sick and tired of this. It is a charade—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Power Mr. S. Power
Speaker.P: Check the figures—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: I ask Deputy Penrose to resume his seat—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: I know exactly what this is about. I know because I come from that background—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: I ask the Deputy to resume his seat. He knows he is being disorderly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: I have never been disorderly.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: The Deputy is being disorderly and I ask him to resume his seat.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Penrose Mr. Penrose
Speaker.P: I am fighting on behalf of the people who were wronged—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: I ask the Deputy to resume his seat.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: What was the answer?

P.i: (Interruptions.)

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: When will the Social Welfare Bill come before the House?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: The Bill will be presented after the budget and its provisions will be contained in the budget.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Crowe Mr. Crowe
Speaker.P: When will the Government bring forward legislation to implement in full the recommendations of the task force on dyslexia delivered to the Department of Education last year?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: There is no legislation promised in that regard.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: There will be plenty of dyslexia in the Book of Estimates.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Ring Mr. Ring
Speaker.P: What does the Ceann Comhairle have against me? I was the second person to put my hand up this morning. When the Contractual Obligations Bill comes before the House, will it mean that when people post a letter in Dublin, it will arrive in rural Ireland and the postman will deliver it?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: The Deputy must ask questions appropriate to legislation not its content.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Ring Mr. Ring
Speaker.P: I ask for the Ceann Comhairle's help as a Member of this House. Can the Minister for Defence – and he is the Government's defence as the Taoiseach is on his day off for his FÁS scheme – ensure that we have a discussion about the postal dispute? Thousands of people have not received their letters this morning in rural Ireland. That is an important issue to this House.
Deputy Parlon talks about selling public buildings and if he keeps going this way, he will sell this House and rent it out for dances.

Speaker.hpid: Cecilia Keaveney Cecilia Keaveney
Speaker.P: That was last week's joke.

P.i: (Interruptions.)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Ring Mr. Ring
Speaker.P: Deputy Cassidy can book the bands.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: The first question on legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: This is a technical Bill and work is proceeding on it. It is impossible to say when it will be introduced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Speaker.P: It is a shame the Taoiseach is not obliged to be here this morning to answer for the Government's shameful reneging on medical cards.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Does the Deputy have a question appropriate to the Order of Business?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Speaker.P: Will the Ceann Comhairle sponsor a change in the Standing Orders so that the Taoiseach is obliged to come to the House on Thursday mornings to answer for crimes such as those announced yesterday by the Government—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Standing Orders are a matter for the Members of the House not for the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Speaker.P: It has deprived vulnerable people of medical cards. Will the Ceann Comhairle bring forward changes?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: The Deputy is out of Order and he knows he is. We must have a question appropriate to legislation. We have not heard anything about legislation yet.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Speaker.P: It is clear that change to Standing Orders should not have been made—

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: That does not arise. The Deputy will have to find another way of raising the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Ms Lynch Ms Lynch
Speaker.P: Given that parents will now have to make the decisions they would normally expect their GPs to make as to how sick their children are, will they be protected under the Medical Indemnity Bill?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: We cannot discuss the content of the Bill at this stage. The Deputy will have to find another way of raising the issue. Deputy Jerry Cowley.

Speaker.hpid: Ms Lynch Ms Lynch
Speaker.P: When will the Bill be introduced?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Can the Minister say when the Bill will be introduced?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: The line to Medjugorje has broken down again.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Smith Mr. M. Smith
Speaker.P: It is not on the list of promised legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Ms McManus Ms McManus
Speaker.P: It is on a list of promised legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Ms Lynch Ms Lynch
Speaker.P: I would not have asked the question otherwise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: We will have to go to Medjugorje for the answer.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Is the Medical Indemnity Bill on the list?

P.i: (Interruptions.)

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle An Ceann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Deputies should give the Minister a chance to respond.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Speaker.P: This is another good reason for the Taoiseach to be here. The Minister cannot read – at least the Taoiseach can read the answers even if he cannot speak well in answering our questions.
